SEARCH
Module com.game
Package com.game

Class MyFrame.MySnake

java.lang.Object
com.game.MyFrame.SnakeObject
com.game.MyFrame.MySnake
All Implemented Interfaces:
movable
Enclosing class:
MyFrame
public static class MyFrame.MySnake extends MyFrame.SnakeObject implements movable
Static subclass of MyFrame. This entails that it cannot access any of the object functions of its frame, as it's an object. Should call into question the validity of this implementation.

The general areas of state information set are:

  • The speed of the snake
  • The length of the snake
  • The number of draws needed to travel the length of a snake body part
  • The score of the player
  • The snakes head image
  • The historical list of points where the sneak head had been drawn up
  • The snake head buffer used for rotation
  • The booleans that determined which direction to move

Is an extended implementation of MyFrame.SnakeObject where it adds functionality specialisation for the snake playable object. The general goal of this class is to draw and move the playable snake.

    • draw

      public void draw(Graphics g)
      This adds a point up to the length +1 * num. Essentially, if the snake is of length 1, then it would add a point up to length 9, and then eternally remain adding and removing point 10. It adds a point every draw, thus every position in these points will have moved m pixels either in x or y, where m is speed_XY.

      Functionality on this is explained in drawBody(Graphics).

      Specified by:
      draw in class MyFrame.SnakeObject
      Parameters:
      g - The graphic parameter pertaining to MyFrame

    • eatBody

      public void eatBody()

    • drawBody

      public void drawBody(Graphics g)
      There are a couple components integral to this drawing system. First of all, the 'num' variable is essentially what determines the unit of drawing. The default snake head is of size 25, and thus as the speed increases, the points will need to be drawn faster.

      Moreso, say the snake has a speed of 5. This means on every draw, it will travel 5 pixels. So, I will need 5 draws to travel the equivalent distance of the entire snake. Ie, 25/5 = 5.

      Every point in the list will be drawn one after another, ie every point going up will be travelling a unit of distance, determined by speed_XY, further than the previous element. This makes the very last element the location of the top of the snake, and every other element below it its location history of every frame rendered, determined by MyFrame.MyThread.

      Thus, if on the assumption that the speed is 5, I will need to go in increments of 5 to travel the equivalent of the snakes head. Ie, every 5 draws, I will have travelled 25 pixels. This entails that on every 5th element, I can draw a snake body part without the body parts touching, because every body part is 25 pixels in length. If the speed increase, it will take fewer draws to travel he 25 pixels, thus the value num will decrease on the formula:

      MyFrame.SnakeObject.w/speed_XY

      Parameters:
      g - The graphic parameter pertaining to MyFrame
